description.text: I needed an adaptor plate to mount my tail light to the license-plate-region of my Topeak bike rack. This style of tail light seems pretty common, so I hope this helps someone else out.

After using this for a couple days on the trail, my light did pop out once after a jostling bump. I've temporarily fixed this with a hack -- wrapping a rubber band or hair elastic around it to keep it held down. When I get some more time, I'll be adding a mechanism to help keep it clipped or locked in place. The open scad file even has a lot of the code necessary to build in a clip in comments, but some modifications, iteration, and trial-and-error will be necessary.

author: LightningZepher

description.text:
1.75mm dual Nema 17 extruder design, inspired by Elliot Foster's design, I mostly created out of curiosity but I've used it for a few weeks and it's worked with all the filaments I've tried (PLA, ABS, PC, NinjaFlex, TPU, Nylon). The block has two hinges that can be adjusted with tensioning screws to set the gap between the drive gears. Motors were connected in series (driven with 24V, 1.3A). Whether you want it hooked up in series or parallel will depend on your particular setup (I'm not sure you can drive motors in series with 12V and if you want to hook them up in parallel, you may need high current stepper drivers to get enough torque). Parts:
2 - Nema17 motors (max 22mm shaft)
2 - E3D hobgoblin drive gears
1 - 1/8" threaded bowden coupling
2 - M3 threaded inserts
2 - M3 x 25mm screws
8 - M3 x 10mm screws
1 - optional series motor connector (I got mine from Peter Stoneham)

Printer:

Eustathios

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Can be printed with or without support, but the filament path has some diaphragms that will need to be removed (run a 2mm drill bit through the filament path).

Assembly
  • Remove any diaphragms in the filament path.
  • Install the M3 threaded inserts.
  • Use the 20mm screws to adjust the tension (you might be able to use longer screws and springs instead if you prefer).
  • Install the Hobgoblin drive gears on the motors (do not tighten) - the set screws may need to be trimmed if they stick out too much.
  • Attach both motors to the extruder block, aligning the set screws so they're accessible through the gap in the hinges.
  • Tighten the set screws through the gaps, keeping them aligned with the center of the gap.
  • Install the threaded bowden coupling.
  • Wire up the motors however you like (in series with an adapter board in my case)
  • Run the motors, check for extrusion direction, make sure there isn't any interference between the motors, adjust the tension, and check the tooth marks in the filament are deep enough and symmetric. I usually tighten the tension screws until the hinge gap is about 1.5mm.

You can edit the design in OnShape if you need to make any changes (different drive gears, filament diameter, bowden coupling, etc.). I did not use the more commonly available (and cheaper) MK8 gears since they're cut too deeply to dual drive 1.75mm filament without offsetting them.

Used Tinkercad to make this for a science teacher.

Made a bigger, badder brother to my original Bug Bot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1065468) with some design improvements to make it easier for little hands to assemble: +Built in battery case (I will upload as a separate piece in upcoming days)
--Using metal zip tie idea** from original Bug Bot, the contacts are extremely easy to make.
--Jumper cable cutouts at all battery contacts for solderless connections. The battery pressing up against it gives enough resistance to hold jumpers in.
--Easy to add ON/OFF switch with 2 small screws and a small piece of metal zip tie. (OR, you can place a jumper between the two batteries for constant power.) +Bug shaped base/body +Larger area for vibration motor. NOTE: I am aware that spiders have 8 legs versus 6 (hence the name "BUG Bot" and not "Spider Bot.") I experimented with 8 legs and found it to be a more difficult setup than 6 (especially for little hands.) If you want to make it more accurate, you can easily drill two more holes. Happy building and good luck! **I don't work or sell the metal zip ties, just sharing a cool idea I had that worked better than I had expected :-)

After having much difficulty using the other corebox that I previously made, I decided that it would be easier to just have 2 or 3 coreboxes for the sizes I really needed.
There is 3 sizes, 1/2 inch, 5/8 inch, and 3/4 inch. The holder_corebox, print two and you'll probably have to file on them very slightly till the coreboxes can be slid in and out while being still snug. Just slip those over each end and it'll hold the coreboxes together while ramming the sand in firmly. 
There is also two sizes of bushings, I tend to design pulleys and such with a half inch bore on here, but hate to have multiple patterns for the same item that has different sized bores, so I the bushings fit over the half inch rod up against the pulleys or whatever you use and it'll leave a cavity for a core in that size instead of the half inch rod.

Stand for a small tablet. Designed for a Nexus7 (2012) though I'm sure it would fit other 7" tablets just fine.
Since my tablet is permanently in place as my 3D printer host I use the gap under the tablet to hold a low profile USB hub.

EDIT:
New version up. Should be a bit stronger to hold heavier tablets.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes: Print it side on, you will need some support under the arches unless you are a bridging master. I printed with a 1.3mm thick wall (so almost completely solid) to make sure it was good and strong. Depends how heavy your tablet is and how rough you are with your stand... There isn't much contact area with the bed, so I strongly suggest a brim at least 5 lines wide to ensure everything sticks down nicely. I also find the brim helps keep the support material stuck to the bed too.

description.text:
I needed a Y Idler that maximized the space I had on the Y-axis. I needed to do a print that pushed to the absolute edges of the build plate. It works just as good as the i3 rework but is smaller in size and uses a smaller bearing. You'll need:
1 4mm bolt and nut
1 5mm bolt and nut
2 5mm washers
1 605Z bearing Sandwich the bearing in between the washers and then insert into idler.
Screw the 5mm bolt through and tighten it with a nut on the opposite side, use threadlocker to make sure its stays put. Enjoy, feedback/suggestions always appreciated. Released through my company: http://northernlayers.com

description.text:
This is a bridge and overhang test piece.  It will test open space bridging from 5 to 15 mm and unsupported straight overhangs from 1 to 5 mm.  The bridging and overhangs all take place at the same level off the bed to eliminate effects from the radiant heat of the bed for evaluating the different spans and extensions.
The files include a Cura pre-scaled (CS) and oriented print ready part and a source file that will import into a modeling program with scene units in inches and object units in mm's.
For me a 15 mm bridge exhibits almost no sagging (less that 0.1mm) and the 4 mm overhang was flat at the third layer (by 0.3mm total thickness).  The 5 mm overhang was flat by the fourth layer and seems to be the practical limit for horizontal straight overhangs.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: A part cooling fan and directed duct work is required for this to successfully test. Print speed was at 40 mm/s. PLA temp at 200C and bed at 50C. Part cooling fan at 100% speed. Top and bottom surfaces set at 0.6mm thick.

title: Modular Hotend Mount for Prometheus V2 Hotend

description.text:
Modified for my Prometheus V2 Hotend, Using a 40mm Fan, printed lower fan duct (focus air flow to heat sink.   Used the MPX connection adapter with Tramming / Bed leveling mount for inductive sensor. 
Included: SketchUp files 
EDIT:  I was having trouble with Auto Bed Leveling and figured out that my E3D Lite6 HotEnd was up 2mm in the mount and was flush with Inductive Sensor - Hot End needed to be 1-2mm further down past sensor for unobstructed printing from sensor.   Added the following part with notch 2mm recessed ledge.   e3d_bowden_mount_b_8.2mm.stl

title: MD80 Camera mount for MJX X400 quadcopter

description.text:
Simple mount adapter to attach an MD80 spy cam to an MJX X400 quadcopter. The design should allow an "ear bud" stalk to be used as a pin, I used philips screw drivers to splay the ends of the pin and a soldering iron to make a notch so it can't fall out. The idea is that the camera should pivot under its own weight after take off.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAXnhmKaazA&feature= The mount screws into the same fastening locations as the C400x cameras that are normally used with the MJX X400. I did also remove the internal battery from the MD80 and fashion a connector that connects it directly to the C4005 power source, but it turns out the voltage drop when under power is enough to cause the MD80 to powerdown, so I don't recommend wasting your time trying this, I did not test the C4002 socket to see if it might have better performance.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
Clean up Most likely you will need to clean up the slot and pin holes to allow the pin (ear bud stalk) and camera to move freely in the mount. The pin is normally a tight fit in the camera itself.

title: Portable GoPro Grip with Teradek Holder

description.text: I regularly us my GoPro's with a Teradek Bolt Video transmitter, usually cable tying everything together, but I needed something that could be portable as well as have the ability to be mounted if necessary. I borrowed the handle from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135198 and built the rest around this. There is a open slot on the one side for all the various Bolt connectors. The front mount for the GoPro needs to move up slightly, until I get around to this, I used the following clamp: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247008 There is also a mount on the top of the unit for other accessories / or a phone mount to view the live feed, or to mount the GoPro. In order to stabilize the unit when it's placed on a flat surface I ended up adding the slanted lip at the bottom front of the unit. The pouch for the Teradek could also house a different transmitter (e.g. Kramer KW-11). I still need to find a shorter HDMI cable, but for now it works :) Any comments / suggestions are welcome.

title: Electrophoretic tissue clearing chamber for CLARITY

description.text: Version 2: less tight for top and chamber fitting. Tighter pressure against the O-ring too.

This chamber was designed for the electrophoretic tissue clearing process for CLARITY. The designs were based off the dimensions found in the protocol (http://clarityresourcecenter.org/). The top thing has extensions on the inside bottom that slide down the slits on the top of the chamber thing. An o-ring can be fitted around the top of the chamber to create a seal when the top is slid down and the extensions are turned between the groove and o-ring. We use the o-ring 9557K165 from McMaster-Carr (though a smaller diameter one would probably work better). There are small holes for a wire to feed through the back, but you will probably have to drill through them to make it bigger. They are mainly used as guides. This model is still in the making. If you try it out and have any suggestions, they would be appreciated.

description.text:
The fan's guard most easy to use and very safety. You won't need screw, complications.. you only have put it in the right position, press and enjoy. It is fixed by pressure itself. You have 3 styles. Search it ;):
1- Simple
2- Honey

Using the following options: BlockLength = 6

Name = AARON

This is our X-Carriage prototype mark up for a project currently in the development stages. Carriage is a single uni-body design with inner reinforcement arches eliminating the need to use support to print. Basic Features: Dual Hot end Ports w/ 24 mm Hot end Barrels and 8 x 16 mm neck mounting rings. (sized for E3D EV6 Hot ends - using remote set direct drive extruders w/ bowden add on.)..
Internal / isolated dynamic hot end cooling ports.w/ internally mounted 30 mm fans.
Low profile / low drag body w/ integrated low friction nylon bearings. (you can use standard reprap bearing in place if necessary.)
Wire management channels
More to come...
There are several other much more impressive features currently in development.
Optional external fan mounts (single and dual) will be posted in the near future as well. If you have any ideas/suggestions, like the design, or hate the design, no matter your feeling we'd appreciate your feedback. We only request, what ever your response, that you give specific reasons, so they can be considered and addressed. We will of course give credit where credit is due at the time of production. Thanks RepRap Community!
SearlsTech, Inc Print Settings Rafts: No
Supports: No
Resolution: 0.2 Layer Height
Infill: 0.25 infil (we use hexagon)
Notes:
We've printed in PLA & PETG w/ no issue. Recommend printing w/ PETG or PET+ @ 230C (bed - 70C)
-Printed at 110 mm/s without issue. ABS Prints - Recommend enclosed printer or draping thick bath towel loosely over the printer opening to limit warping due to ambient air. ABS at 235C (Bed @ 105C - for 2-4 layers then reducing bed temps to 95C - reduces warping) Recommend Robo or Solutech ABS filament for best results.

I will update again when I have a chance to print this in ABS.

A simple Goodman Handle which i have designed for my Hartenberger Videolight-Head.

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.3

25% -100%

Notes: Printed in PLA or ABS.
Simple handle for screw-mounting with through-hole and rounded ends.

Part is oriented with the screw end down, so as to print without support. You may need to use a raft if your bottom width, radius and hole dimensions do not leave enough surface area for adhesion to your build platform. I was able to print one in PLA on blue tape without a raft.
Variables screw_head and screw_shaft are diameter measurements of the screw you intend to use. Leave a little extra for clearance. Screw_sink is the amount of material that will be left between the bottom of the handle and the top of the screw hole. Too low a value will weaken the part; too high and your screw may not penetrate enough. Resolution affects outside curves only. Leave high for a smoother part, or experiment with a lower value for a faceted appearance.
If you want the bottom edge flat, use a very small value for bottom_radius, like 0.1, but not zero.

description.text:
Make your FPV experience better with all in one FPV station. Display, receiver and battery in one small device. You will need:
RC832 receiver
5" LCD-TFT display - ebay
M3 screws and nuts
Soldering iron
some wires
Multimeter
Li-pol 3S1P or other 12V DC. Assembly:
Disassembly RC832, plug video jack in and check with diode test, which pin is video signal, then solder wire to the pin. Do the same with DC jack + and - polarity and solder wires. Disassembly LCD. Solder video signal and power supply to LCD logic board. Isolate all electronic parts ( I used kapton tape).
Now put it all together.

12 copies of this shape form a sphere based on the structure of a dodecahedron. The addition of magnets on the sides means that you can assemble this object very quickly and have a nice stable shape. Furthermore you can assemble the object by putting the 12 pieces in a box and shaking the box. This was inspired by a video on self-assembling viruses.

You will need 12 copies of the piece and 120 small cube magnets. If you print at 100% you need 2mm magnets, I found that printing at 150% scale and using 3mm magnets gave a more stable structure that self-assembled more quickly when shaken. The edges of the pentagons are not straight by design: this seems to speed up the self-assembly process.  
Getting all 120 magnets in place is tedious. The magnets must alternate in polarity going around the shape. Thus on any one side, there must be a north and south pole. These must be the same order on each face (say north on the left, south on the right). As long as you can get one piece done correctly (check it thoroughly by using a bar of the remaining magnets!), there is a simple trick to complete the other 11 pieces which is to attach 10 more magnets around the finished piece, and then just push pairs of magnets into another piece.  This is illustrated in the last pair of images above.  
You will probably need to glue the magnets in. I found that on my printer (an ultimaker) I couldn't get the tolerance right so that all the holes were tight enough to hold the magnets: sometimes I thought I had been successful but then magnets would fall out a few days later. Superglue is fine for this process.  
Note

Based on communication with Dr. Arthur Olson, the author of the video that inspired this design, I would like note that the invention behind this design is protected under his U.S. patent 20100168439 "Self-Assembled Polyhedra," and that any commercial sale or use of this model or any model that incorporates the concepts described in the patent is prohibited without proper licensing from Dr. Olson

author: Pelaburro

title: Quick release Y plates for Prusa simplified mendel

description.text:
There aren't that many files around for cutting the small and large Y plates.
Here's what I made. I went for the same magnets-plus-socket-cap system I used on the X carrriage, largely inspired by the Cupcake build platform.
The largest plate was carved to save on weight and allow more leeway for the tensioners et al. (check out the "automatic belt tensioner", if there is ever some slack in the Y belt just slightly unscrew one the holders and it gets the axis back under tension. Will be checking how long the spring takes to cut through the Y belt loops of course ;)
So far, all works reasonably well.

Tis is the last recycling use of a broken Ikea stool (smirk), it was made of 8 mm thick MDF. After routing it and fixing the magnets with cyanoacrylate glue (be extra careful to keep complementary poles betwen the upper and lower plates), I soaked it in fluid epoxy and allowed it to cure for a couple of days... works wonders to stabilize MDF. The holes for the socket caps may need some rework after that tratment. Retrospectively I'd go for a lighter assembly and use thinner (6 mm) MDF plates excepted for the intermediary pieces. And you can also lasercut 6 mm sheet.
Greg Frost's LM8UU holders were epoxied (as well as the LM8UU bearings themselves, no bolts nor zip ties were used.
The upper aluminium plate has the hole distances set for PrusaJr's PCB heater (209mm apart), mounted on springs, but not yet tried. The holes in the aluminium plate were slightly enlarged, while the caps of the corresponding bolts were epoxied to the MDF plate.

Everybody loves the living hinge but sometimes you need something functional that can actually be load bearing. I designed this hinge for the lid of a box, it prevents the lid from flapping all the way open and is sturdy enough to hold the lid tight. This and all my other items can be found on my blog http://msraynsford.blogspot.co.uk/2013/06/hinged-success.html

The overlapping region of each hinge layer is etched to prevent the hinge from binding when the layers are stacked up. An M4 bolt is put through the middle of hinge with a nylock nut and the end caps hide the bolt away. The 2 different layers in the middle of the hinge prevent the hinge opening wider than 110 degrees so the lid of the box will fall and stay open, but will not bed all the way back and snap off.

title: Mendel: Prusa  durable z-axis motor coupling

description.text:
This is a design for a new, more durable flexible coupling (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupling) for use on the z-axis motors in the Mendel: Prusa RepRap machine design. The design allows for 2-3 degrees of play, but can be adjusted depending on how it's machined. Please see the following YouTube link that shows the an animated CAD simulation of the design:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PQEHnb5eVaE
and here is the design manufactured and in use:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hu32DFF1TXY
The RepRap machine filmed in the above video is one of the two Mendel: Prusa machines located at the Digital Manufacturing Laboratory in Bath.
http://digitalmanufacturinglab.com/

Start with some round bar with minimum diameter 14mm and minimum length 25mm. On a lathe, face off one end making sure to use coolant where needed. Next, ensuring that the lathe headstock is concentric, centre drill the recently machined face and drill a 5mm diameter through hole. Turn the bar around in the lathe and face off the other end. Drill a 6.5mm diameter hole 15mm deep - note there is no need to centre drill as the 5mm hole runs through the entire rod length. Disengage the lathe clutch so the chuck can be turned by hand freely. With an M8 tap in the head stock, using cutting lubricant, cut an M8 thread into the 6.5mm diameter hole you have just drilled.
File a flat onto the end of the part which has the 5mm hole. Insert just enough of the motor shaft into the 5mm hole so that approximately 2mm of the shaft is past the 3mm through hole. Clamp the motor and part securely so they do not move independently. Drill into the 3mm hole again, this time cutting going through the motor shaft as well as the part.
Assembly: insert the motor shaft into the 5mm diameter hole, use an M3 hex bolt, M3 washers and an M3 nylock to attach it. Screw an M8 plain nut onto the z-axis stud, screw the stud into the M8 thread of the part and then tighten the M8 nut up to the part.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Ultimate Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder - 30mm version

description.text: This is a minor tweak to AndrewBCN's extruder to reduce the gap between the pinch and the filament channel. Too large a gap here allows flexible filament like NinjaFlex or PolyFlex to twist and push out of the extruder from the side instead of being forced down into the hot end. With this smaller opening the flexible filament does not have a chance to escape. I also made the filament guide wider on one side because the tips were too narrow to print reliably and cleanly when configured for 3mm filament. It should be wider on both sides, but I need to carve out a space for it on the extruder body for that to fit, and I haven't done that yet. This thing is managed on github.

Nov 12, 2015 Update 1:
The .scad file is set for 1.75mm filament by default and the .stl files are built for both 1.75mm and 3mm filament extruder configurations. I corrected the STL so the 1.75mm version guilder will lay flat on the print bed. But I have not tested the 1.75mm version myself. Let me know if you have any trouble with it. Also, I renamed the files to match this thing's name and to avoid confusion with AndrewBCN's version.

I found the original idea for this solution in a video by Christopher Hoffman (youtube:BZSo7CT914Y) which also explains the original problem quite well.  I tried to use his fix, modifying my original Wade's Greg's extruder, but I messed it up because I was using a hand drill and wasn't very precise.
